question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $\mathbf{A} =\begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix}.$  Then there exist scalars $p$ and $q$ such that
\[\mathbf{A}^6 = p \mathbf{A} + q \mathbf{I}.\]Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$
inference:
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.$  We compute
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1(-1) + 2(3) & -1(2) + 2(4) \\ 3(-1) + 4(3) & 3(2) + 4(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^3 &= \begin{pmatrix} 7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7(-1) + 6(3) & 7(2) + 6(4) \\ 9(-1) + 22(3) & 9(2) + 22(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 11 & 34 \\ 63 & 110 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^4 &= \begin{pmatrix} 11 & 34 \\ 63 & 110 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 11(-1) + 34(3) & 11(2) + 34(4) \\ 63(-1) + 110(3) & 63(2) + 110(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 101 & 166 \\ 297 & 506 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^5 &= \begin{pmatrix} 101 & 166 \\ 297 & 506 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 101(-1) + 166(3) & 101(2) + 166(4) \\ 297(-1) + 506(3) & 297(2) + 506(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 401 & 800 \\ 1179 & 2500 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Finally,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^6 &= \begin{pmatrix} 401 & 800 \\ 1179 & 2500 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 401(-1) + 800(3) & 401(2) + 800(4) \\ 1179(-1) + 2500(3) & 1179(2) + 2500(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1997 & 4002 \\ 6021 & 12500 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}We have $\mathbf{A}^6 = 1997 \mathbf{A} + 1 \mathbf{I}.$
Final Answer: $\boxed{(1997, 1)}$
ground_truth:
Note that
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix}  7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 3 \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + 10 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Squaring the equation $\mathbf{A}^2 = 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I},$ we get
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^4 &= (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I})^2 \\
&= 9 \mathbf{A}^2 + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 9 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Then
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^6 &= \mathbf{A}^4 \cdot \mathbf{A}^2 \\
&= (87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I})(3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) \\
&= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$

question:

\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^3 &= \begin{pmatrix} 7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7(-1) + 6(3) & 7(2) + 6(4) \\ 9(-1) + 22(3) & 9(2) + 22(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 11 & 34 \\ 63 & 110 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^4 &= \begin{pmatrix} 11 & 34 \\ 63 & 110 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 11(-1) + 34(3) & 11(2) + 34(4) \\ 63(-1) + 110(3) & 63(2) + 110(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 101 & 166 \\ 297 & 506 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^5 &= \begin{pmatrix} 101 & 166 \\ 297 & 506 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 101(-1) + 166(3) & 101(2) + 166(4) \\ 297(-1) + 506(3) & 297(2) + 506(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 401 & 800 \\ 1179 & 2500 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Finally,
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^6 &= \begin{pmatrix} 401 & 800 \\ 1179 & 2500 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 401(-1) + 800(3) & 401(2) + 800(4) \\ 1179(-1) + 2500(3) & 1179(2) + 2500(4) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1997 & 4002 \\ 6021 & 12500 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}We have $\mathbf{A}^6 = 1997 \mathbf{A} + 1 \mathbf{I}.$

inference:
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.$  We want to find $\mathbf{A}^6.$ We calculate $\mathbf{A}^2,$ $\mathbf{A}^3,$ $\mathbf{A}^4,$ $\mathbf{A}^5,$ and $\mathbf{A}^6.$
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix}, \\ \mathbf{A}^3 &= \begin{pmatrix} 11 & 34 \\ 63 & 110 \end{pmatrix}, \\ \mathbf{A}^4 &= \begin{pmatrix} 101 & 166 \\ 297 & 506 \end{pmatrix}, \\ \mathbf{A}^5 &= \begin{pmatrix} 401 & 800 \\ 1179 & 2500 \end{pmatrix}, \\ \mathbf{A}^6 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1997 & 4002 \\ 6021 & 12500 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}We want to find $a$ and $b$ such that
\[ \mathbf{A}^6 = a \mathbf{A} + b \mathbf{I}. \]Then
\begin{align*} \mathbf{A}^6 = a \mathbf{A} + b \mathbf{I} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1997 & 4002 \\ 6021 & 12500 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= a \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + b \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} -a + b & 2a \\ 3a & 4a + b \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Comparing entries,
\begin{align*} -a + b &= 1997, \\ 2a &= 4002, \\ 3a &= 6021, \\ 4a + b &= 12500. \end{align*}From $2a = 4002,$ $a = 2001.$  Then $3a = 6003,$ which is consistent with the third equation.  Also, $4(2001) + b = 12500,$ so $8004 + b = 12500,$ $b = 4496.$  Then $-2001 + 4496 = 2495,$ so $b = 1997 \neq 2495.$
From $2a = 4002,$ $a = 2001.$  Then $4a + b = 12500,$ so $8004 + b = 12500,$ and $b = 4496.$  Also, $-a + b = -2001 + 4496 = 2495 \neq 1997.$

Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{(1997, 4496)}$

Note that
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}  -1 & 2 \\  3 & 4  \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix}  7 & 6 \\ 9 & 22 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 3 \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + 10 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Squaring the equation $\mathbf{A}^2 = 3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I},$ we get
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^4 &= (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I})^2 \\
&= 9 \mathbf{A}^2 + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 9 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 60 \mathbf{A} + 100 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Then
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^6 &= \mathbf{A}^4 \cdot \mathbf{A}^2 \\
&= (87 \mathbf{A} + 190 \mathbf{I})(3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) \\
&= 261 \mathbf{A}^2 + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 261 (3 \mathbf{A} + 10 \mathbf{I}) + 1440 \mathbf{A} + 1900 \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2223 \mathbf{A} + 4510 \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Thus, $(p,q) = \boxed{(2223,4510)}.$
